Minesweeper: How to play

Minesweeper is a deceptively simple test of memory and reasoning—and one of the most popular Windows games of all time. The goal: find the empty squares and avoid the mines.

To start a game

  1. At the main screen, tap on New Game.
  2. Choose a difficulty level - Beginner, Intermediate, or Expert
  3. The screen will change to display the appropriate tiles.
  4. To start, tap on a tile.
  5. You may also choose to create a custom game by tapping on the Options button.

Rules & Basics

The objective

Find the empty squares while avoiding the mines.

The board

Minesweeper has three standard boards to choose from, each progressively more difficult.

  • Beginner: 64 tiles, 10 mines
  • Intermediate: 256 tiles, 40 mines
  • Expert: 480 tiles, 99 mines

How to play

The rules in Minesweeper are simple:

  • Uncover a mine, and the game ends.
  • Uncover an empty square, and you keep playing.
  • Uncover a number, and it tells you how many mines lay hidden in the eight surrounding squares - information you use to deduce which nearby squares are safe to click.

Hints and Tips

Study the patterns. If three squares in a row display 2-3-2, then you know three mines are probably lined up beside that row. If a square says 8, every surrounding square has a mine.

Explore the unexplored. Not sure where to click next? Try clearing some unexplored territory. You\'re better off clicking in the middle of unmarked squares than in an area you suspect has a mine.
